div1.p: Howard reflects on his lifetime of work with mosquitoes. He includes a transcript of a January 13, 1901 letter from Walter Reed describing the success of Reed's experiments. A transcript of a February 20, 1902 letter from Ronald Ross discusses Ross' work in Africa.

FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD

p.hi: WRITTEN BY DR. L. O. HOWARD

div1.p:
Many of my relatives and friends have caused me much embarrassment
from time to time by unintentionally exaggerating the importance of the
work I happen to have done concerning mosquitoes that carry disease, and
even certain newspapers and magazines have also greatly overstated the
importance of what I have done.

So I think it best in this memorandum to give a clear statement
of my work in this direction, in order that I may not be accused at any
time of claiming credit which I did not deserve.

I have been an entomologist of a kind since boyhood days, and
specialized in entomology through my undergraduate degrees at Cornell.
A post-graduate course of one year was devoted to studies preparatory to
medicine, and in the early eighties I took a partial course in medicine
at Columbian University in Washington, and have always been interested
in medical matters, particularly in questions of public health, and have
associated with medical men.

In 1867, when a boy of ten years of age, I used kerosene in a
horse-trough in which mosquitoes were breeding at Ithaca, N. Y. In
June, 1892 I conducted an experiment with a pool having a surface area
of sixteen square feet in Greene County, New York. I published an account
of this experiment in Insect Life, Volume V, pages 12 to 14, published
September, 1892. The introductory paragraph read, “One of the most
reasonable of the recommendations which have been made from time to time
and which look toward the reduction of the mosquito plague during the
summer months is the application of kerosene to restricted and fishless
breeding ponds. Although this remedy has often been suggested, I know
of no careful records of actual experiments, and consequently deem the
following account of a recent experience worthy of publication.” I then
go on to show that not only does the kerosene application kill the wrigglers
and pupae, but that it does not deter adult mosquitoes from alighting on
the water and attempting to drink or to lay eggs, thus being caught and
killed by the kerosene film. I estimated the amount of kerosene to be
used as approximately one ounce to fifteen square feet of surface, and
indicated that in midsummer it would be effective up to from a week to
ten days. This announcement was copied widely in the newspapers and was
speedily followed by extensive use of kerosene for this purpose in different
parts of the country, and thus really formed a practical basis for the
work of this kind which has been done since.

In 1896, in a bulletin on household insects (No. 4, new series,
Division of Entomology, U. S. Department of Agriculture), I published a
chapter on mosquitoes and fleas, in the preparation of which I carefully
studied the biology of Culex pipiens (under the name of Culex pungens) and
published a full account from original observations for the first time
since Rėamur (150 years earlier), and mentioned the finding of Anopheles
quadrimaculatus (now known as a prominent malaria carrier) and the obtaining

of its eggs, rearing operations being interrupted by a necessary field
trip. In this article the question of mosquito remedies was considered
at some length.

Later I followed out the full life history of the malarial
species, Anopheles quadrimaculatus, and, following the discovery of the
relations of Anopheles and malaria, lectured in the spring of 1900 before
the Royal Society of Canada and before the Section of Theory and Practice
of Medicine of the American Association at the annual meeting of the
Association in Atlantic City on the subject of the biology of Anopheles
as contrasted with that of Culex, illustrating both lectures with lantern
slides showing the different stages of A. quadrimaculatus and C. pipiens.
A full account of the biology of both species, with ten original illus-
trations, was published in the Scientific American, Vol. 83, p. 809, July
7, 1900. This was the first published account of the full life history
of an American species of Anopheles.

This was immediately followed, July 24, 1900, by the publication
of Bulletin 25, new series, Division of Entomology, entitled “Notes on
the Mosquitoes of the United States, giving some account of their structure
and biology with remarks' on remedies.” In the letter of transmittal it
was stated that the bulletin “gives some account of the structure and
biology (of mosquitoes) and indicates the differences in all stages of
existence between the kinds of mosquitoes which have been shown to
transmit malaria and those which do not. It also treats of the subject
of remedies in considerable detail. It has been written mainly from the
popular standpoint, although scientific details of structure and classi-
fication have been inserted for the use of physicians engaged in studying
malaria.”

During the early months of 1900 I was visited by Dr. W. S. Thayer
of Johns Hopkins University and Dr. Jesse W. Lazear of Baltimore, who
wished my assistance in clearing up certain points in regard to mosquitoes,
since they were at that time engaged in the study of malaria. This was
of special interest on account of Doctor Thayer's standing as an authority
upon malaria and on account of Doctor Lazear's subsequent connection with
the Yellow Fever Commission and his sad death during the progress of its
investigations. I had the pleasure a little later of delivering a joint
lecture with Doctor Thayer under the auspices of the Maryland Board of
Health, Doctor Thayer treating of malaria and I myself handling the
malarial mosquitoes.

It was during the summer of 1900 that the Army Yellow Fever
Commission was appointed by Surgeon-General Sternberg, and Doctor Reed
and Doctor Carroll of the Commission came frequently to the Department
of Agriculture to study mosquitoes, and during the progress of their in-
vestigations in Cuba I was in frequent correspondence with Doctor Reed,
who consulted this office in regard to all mosquito points. The following
quotation from a letter received just after the final conclusion of the
implication of the yellow fever mosquito in the carriage of disease is of
keen interest:

FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD

Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
January 13, 1901.
Dear Mr. Howard:

I am in receipt of yours of January 5th, and thank you very
much for the card containing Dr. Wolfert's suggestion. I turned the
card over to the Chief Surgeon, yesterday. I enclose a copy of the order
relating to protection against mosquitoes. Of course, you have already
heard from Dr. Sternberg of our complete success in repeating our former
observations. The mosquito theory for the propagation of yellow fever
is no longer a theory, but a well established fact. Isn't it enough to
make a fellow feel happy? Anopheles and Culex are a gay old pair! What
havoc they have wrought on our species during the last three centuries!
But with “Howard and kerosene,” we are going to knock them out!
With best wishes,
Sincerely yours,
(Signed) WALTER REED.

Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U.S.A., was the Acting Chief Surgeon
of the Division of Cuba, at the time this order was published, and it was
he who drew it up and recommended it to Gen. Wood. He should have credit
for it.
W. R.

The reference to General Sternberg in this letter was made since
Doctor Reed knew that I was in the habit of meeting General Sternberg
(at that time Surgeon General in the Army) almost daily and talking over
matters of common interest. In fact I talked often with the General on
this subject of the carriage of disease by mosquitoes, and, since I was
busy that summer working on the insect fauna of human excrement with
special reference to the carriage of typhoid, which will be referred to
later, we had many conversations on the subject of typhoid in the Army
FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
-4-
concentration camps during 1898.

Mosquito notes and additional observations on different species
were constantly being made, and in the spring of 1901, just after the com-
pletion of the manuscript of the Insect Book I began to prepare the manu-
script which was subsequently published as “Mosquitoes; How they Live;
How they Carry Disease; How they are Classified; How they may be Destroyed.”
I had thought of publishing this book privately, and had been in corres-
pondence with the Macmillan Company about it, but one day early in 1901
Mr. Samuel Hopkins Adams, at that time connected with McClure Phillips &
Company, came into my office (I had done some work for the McClure
syndicate through him) and asked me what I was doing. I told him about
the mosquito book, and he asked me not to close arrangements until he
could consult his firm. Within a few days I got a favorable offer from
McClure Phillips & Company, and they subsequently published the book in
the early summer.

A few days later the late Dr. E. A. De Schweinitz came to me
and said that he had heard some Army people at the Chevy Chase Club talking
vigorously about the way in which I had treated Doctor Reed in the book,
and I then became aware for the first time that, contrary to what I had
stated on pages 122 and 123 of the book, Doctor Reed had undertaken his
mosquito investigations in Havana on his own initiative and without suggestion
from the Surgeon General. I was at that time preparing an article for
the Review of Reviews on this general subject, and I immediately went to
the Army Medical Museum to explain matters to Doctor Reed. He received
me very kindly, and said that he could readily see how I had fallen into
the error, and read the manuscript of the Review of Reviews article, which
I worded in exact accordance with the facts as I gained them from
Doctor Reed (See the American Monthly Review of Reviews, August 1, 1901,
pp. 192-195, and especially the matter on p. 194). Reference should also
be made here to an illustrated article of mine in the Century Magazine
for April, 1901, pages 941-949, entitled “Malaria and Certain Mosquitoes,”
and to another illustrated article in the same magazine for October,
1903, on “Yellow Fever and Mosquitoes,” pages 851-857.

Doctor Reed died November 22, 1902. Dr. Howard A. Kelly, in
his book entitled “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever,” published by McClure
Phillips & Company in 1906, on pages 251-252 has the following: “During
the winter following Doctor Reed's death a strong desire arose among his
friends as to the establishment of some memorial in his honor. The
project first assumed definite shape at a dinner given by Prof. Alexander
Graham Bell to a number of the members of the Association of American
Scientists,” etc., etc. This dinner was given during Convocation Week,
and if I remember rightly on December 31st. It was a large dinner, and
many prominent American scientific men were present as well as my dear
old friend Dr. James Fletcher from Ottawa, Canada. As is always the case
at Doctor Bell's dinners, there came a time when one person was asked to
speak to all the rest, interrupting general conversation. This night
Doctor Gilman, formerly President of Johns Hopkins University, with whom
I had been talking about Reed and his discoveries, suggested that Doctor
Bell should call upon me to tell them all what I had been telling him, and
so I told the story as effectively as I knew how, and I hope that the
forcible way in which I know I told it helped to inspire the movement for
the memorial which afterwards materialized.

FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD

My interest in mosquitoes was so great and important observations
were accumulating so rapidly, and the McClures declining to undertake a
radical revision of the mosquito book which was soon out of date as to
very important biological facts and as to matters of classification, I
memorialized the newly founded Carnegie Institution of Washington in
April, 1902, asking for a grant to enable the preparation of a monograph
to include all possible information concerning all mosquitoes in North
and Central American and the West Indies. The grant was made by the trustees
in January, 1903, and the work was carried on through subsequent years.
The story is told in the introduction to Volume 1 of the monograph.

Incidentally I became interested in the geographic distribution
in North America of the yellow fever mosquito, and the Public Health
Service in November, 1903, published a pamphlet which I wrote entitled
“Concerning the Geographic Distribution of the Yellow Fever Mosquito.”
In the course of the investigation upon which this paper was based I
utilized the entomological service of the Department of Agriculture, and
myself visited Mexico and followed out some interesting points regarding
the altitude which this species reaches in that country. This happened
to be the year of the Laredo outbreak of yellow fever, and I was forced
to return to this country by sea in order to avoid quarantine at the Texas
border. This pamphlet was later revised, and it was the basis of the
quarantine work which was carried on by the Public Health Service during
the summer of 1905, the year of the last outbreak of the fever at New Orleans.
I was in Europe that summer, and the first news which reached me on
landing at New York was of the condition of New Orleans and of the death
of my old friend, Archbishop Chappell in the course of the epidemic. As
soon as I could arrange business matters in Washington, I went south, and,
having to visit Texas, was obliged to go to that State first, since if
I went to New Orleans first I would not have been permitted to enter Texas.
But I reached New Orleans late in October, and was greatly interested in
seeing what Dr. J. H. White of the Public Health Service and his able body
of assistants (one of whom was Dr. Rupert Blue, now Surgeon General of the
Public Health Service) had been able to accomplish. A table drawn up by
Doctor Chaille of New Orleans, which he gave to me, and which I have used
many times in lectures, and which is printed in Doctor Kelly's biography
of Doctor Reed on page 196, indicates plainly that at least 3,500 lives
were saved that summer in New Orleans alone by the efficient application
by Doctor White of the facts gained by Doctor Reed and his colleagues
and by the subsequent Army work in Havana carried on by General (then Major)
Gorgas.

I first met Sir Ronald Ross, when he was simply Doctor Ross, in
1904 at the World's Congress of Arts and Sciences in St. Louis, but I had
known him previously by correspondence. In January, 1902, he sent me an
admirable little book entitled “Mosquito Brigades” inscribed on the fly-
leaf “L. O. Howard with the compliments of the author and his regrets that
he had not seen ‘Mosquitoes’ earlier.” I sent him a letter of thanks and
received the following characteristic reply:

FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
Liverpool, Feb. 20th, 1902.
My dear Professor Howard,

I am delighted to hear that you like my ‘Mosquito Brigades.’
However it is not a patch on your work, which I wish I had got hold of
before. I sail for Sierra Leone in two days, and hope to find work pro-
gressing. We have forced the Gambia Colony to take up the same work, and
by dint of constant driving, I think we are getting this old country to
do something at last. It is however doubtless the example of Havana that
has chiefly set them going. We never do anything here unless some other
country takes it up first. Yes, I think that the Italian School requires
a little medicine in the shape of plain speaking. I suppose that you have
seen the last effort of Grassi and Noe, who pretend that they have found
out about Filaria banorofti. As a matter of fact they have hardly ever
seen one, much less found out anything about them.
Believe me,
Yours very sincerely,
Ronald Ross.

Since then I have visited Ross in his laboratories at Liverpool
several times, and we have frequently corresponded; in fact, he asked me
to write a chapter in his big book “The Prevention of Malaria,” which I
did. It may be worth while noting also that Sir William Osler asked me
to write the chapter on mosquitoes which occurs in his great work on
“The Theory and Practice of Medicine” published in 1907.

In 1902 I visited Celli's laboratory in Rome, and saw something
of the early work against malaria on the Roman Campagna. Later, at
Celli's request, I contributed an article to the Atti Soc. Per gli Studi
della Malaria, Volume XI, pages 67-73 (Rome) on “The Gradual Disappearance
of Malaria following the Settlement of a New Country and its Reappearance
as a Result of the Dense Civilization.” In 1910 I visited Rome again,
and with Celli went over portions of the reclaimed Compagna and spent one
of the most enjoyable days of my life with this wonderfully able and delightful
man. At the same time I had the pleasure of meeting Tiraboschi and Grassi
characterized as “Une veritable sottise.” I subsequently published an
FROM L. O. HOWARD
OR LUCY HOWARD
-7-
article on antimalarial work in Italy in the Acts of the Society for the
Study of Malaria, Volume XII (Rome).

It will thus be seen that I had nothing whatever to do with any
of the actual discoveries relating to the carriage of disease by mosquitoes.
I was a pioneer in the practical study of mosquito remedies, and the ad-
vice given both in Bulletin 25 and in the mosquito book has been of
assistance in the fight against these disease-bearing insects. I have been
somewhat of a publicist in this direction by means of numerous articles
in magazines and elsewhere as well as contributions to various scientific
journals.
